information.title: Definition and Concept
information.description: Secularism refers to the principle of separating religion from the state to ensure that all religions are treated equally. In the Indian context, secularism ensures that the state does not favor or discriminate against any religion.

information.title: Constitutional Provisions
information.description: The word 'secular' was added to the Preamble of the Constitution by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976. Articles 25 to 28 guarantee freedom of religion and religious practices.

information.title: Article 25
information.description: This article guarantees all citizens the right to freedom of conscience and the right to profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.

information.title: Article 26
information.description: This article gives every religious denomination or any of its sections the right to manage its own affairs in matters of religion.

information.title: Article 27
information.description: This article prohibits the state from compelling any citizen to pay taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion.

information.title: Article 28
information.description: This article prohibits religious instruction in educational institutions wholly maintained by state funds.

information.title: Challenges to Secularism
information.description: Challenges include communalism, politicization of religion, lack of uniform civil code, and incidents of religious intolerance that threaten the secular fabric of the nation.

information.title: Significance of Secularism
information.description: Secularism ensures the unity and integrity of a diverse country like India. It provides a framework for peaceful coexistence and upholds the democratic ideals of justice, equality, and liberty.
